If the total was $75.50, and you handed them $80.00, the had to figure out to give you back $4.50 cents. There was no computer to do the math, and there was no card to swipe to make the payment.To entertain ourselves, we socialized in real life. We’d go to parties (and once we were old enough, to bars and nightclubs.) We’d talk, dance, or sing, or play card games, or board games. We played in the streets, skipping rope, playing sports like wiffle ball or frisbee.There was bowling and roller skating on special occasions. There were pool halls for adults. People formed softball leagues, and kids played in little leagues. We had a basketball hoop outside on a street pole. We’d ride our bicycles, and generally spent a lot more time outdoors just doing things than kids do today. On rainy or cold days, we’d stay inside and do arts and crafts, or sometimes watch cartoons on TV.Life was dramatically different from how it is today. People didn’t feel the need to share every silly thing that took place during the course of their day, like they do today on social media. We didn’t spend hours talking about news events, or sharing memes. We didn’t take pictures and videos of every blessed thing we saw. We certainly didn’t take so many pictures of ourselves. And the pictures we did take cost money, and there was a limit to the amount of film in the camera, so you chose things you really wanted to remember. You had to get the film developed, and that also cost money and took a few days. You didn’t even know how the pictures would look until you got them back.
